metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: C Structures (structs)
Structures
Structures (also called structs) are a way to group several related variables into one place.
content.html: Structures (also called structs) are a way to group several related variables into one place.

content.text: Each variable in the structure is known as a member of the structure.
content.html: Each variable in the structure is known as a member of the structure.

content.text: Unlike an array , a structure can contain many different data types ( int , float , char , etc.).
content.html: Unlike an array, a structure can contain many different data types (int, float, char, etc.).

content.text: Create a Structure
You can create a structure by using the struct keyword and declare each of its members inside curly braces:
content.html: You can create a structure by using the struct keyword and declare each of its members inside curly braces:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // End the structure with a semicolon

syntax_highlighting.text: // End the structure with a semicolon

content.code_html:
struct MyStructure {   // Structure declaration
  int myNum;           // Member (int variable)
  char myLetter;       // Member (char variable)
}; // End the structure with a semicolon

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // End the structure with a semicolon

content.text: To access the structure, you must create a variable of it.
content.html: To access the structure, you must create a variable of it.

content.text: Use the struct keyword inside the main() method, followed by the name of the structure and then the name of the structure variable:
content.html: Use the struct keyword inside the main() method, followed by the name of the structure and then the name of the structure variable:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
struct myStructure {  int myNum;  char myLetter;};int main() 
  {  struct myStructure s1;  return 0;}

content.code:
struct myStructure {  int myNum;  char myLetter;};int main()
{  struct myStructure s1;  return 0;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
struct myStructure {  int myNum;  char myLetter;};int main() 
  {  struct myStructure s1;  return 0;}

content.code_html:
struct myStructure {
  int myNum;
  char myLetter;
};

int main() {
  struct myStructure s1;
  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
struct myStructure {  int myNum;  char myLetter;};int main() 
  {  struct myStructure s1;  return 0;}

content.text: Access Structure Members
To access members of a structure, use the dot syntax ( . ):
content.html: To access members of a structure, use the dot syntax (.):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create a structure variable 
    of myStructure called s1
// Assign values to members of s1

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create a structure variable 
    of myStructure called s1
// Assign values to members of s1

content.code_html:
// Create a structure called myStructure
struct myStructure {
  int myNum;
  char myLetter;
};

int main() {
  // Create a structure variable of myStructure called s1
  struct myStructure s1;

  // Assign values to members of s1
  s1.myNum = 13;
  s1.myLetter = 'B';

  // Print values
  printf("My number: %d\n", s1.myNum);
  printf("My letter: %c\n", s1.myLetter);

  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create a structure variable 
    of myStructure called s1
// Assign values to members of s1

content.text: Now you can easily create multiple structure variables with different values, using just one structure:
content.html: Now you can easily create multiple structure variables with different values, using just one structure:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Assign values to different struct variables

syntax_highlighting.text: // Assign values to different struct variables

content.code_html:
// Create different struct variables
struct myStructure s1;
struct myStructure s2;

// Assign values to different struct variables
s1.myNum = 13;
s1.myLetter = 'B';

s2.myNum = 20;
s2.myLetter = 'C';

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Assign values to different struct variables

content.text: What About Strings in Structures?
Remember that strings in C are actually an array of characters, and unfortunately, you can't assign a value to an array like this:
content.html: Remember that strings in C are actually an array of characters, and unfortunately, you can't assign a value to an array like this:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Trying to assign a value to the string

syntax_highlighting.text: // Trying to assign a value to the string

content.code_html:
struct myStructure {
  int myNum;
  char myLetter;
  char myString[30];  // String
};

int main() {
  struct myStructure s1;

  // Trying to assign a value to the string
  s1.myString = "Some text";

  // Trying to print the value
  printf("My string: %s", s1.myString);

  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Trying to assign a value to the string

content.text: However, there is a solution for this! You can use the strcpy() function and assign the value to s1.myString , like this:
content.html: However, there is a solution for this! You can use the strcpy() function and assign the value to s1.myString, like this:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Assign a value to the string using 
    the strcpy function

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Assign a value to the string using 
    the strcpy function

content.code_html:
struct myStructure {
  int myNum;
  char myLetter;
  char myString[30]; // String
};

int main() {
  struct myStructure s1;

  // Assign a value to the string using the strcpy function
  strcpy(s1.myString, "Some text");

  // Print the value
  printf("My string: %s", s1.myString);

  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Assign a value to the string using 
    the strcpy function

content.text: Simpler Syntax
You can also assign values to members of a structure variable at declaration time, in a single line.
content.html: You can also assign values to members of a structure variable at declaration time, in a single line.

content.text: Just insert the values in a comma-separated list inside curly braces {} . Note that you don't have to use the strcpy() function for string values with this technique:
content.html: Just insert the values in a comma-separated list inside curly braces {}. Note that you don't have to use the strcpy() function for string values with this technique:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a structure variable and assign values to it

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a structure variable and assign values to it

content.code_html:
// Create a structure
struct myStructure {
  int myNum;
  char myLetter;
  char myString[30];
};

int main() {
  // Create a structure variable and assign values to it
  struct myStructure s1 = {13, 'B', "Some text"};

  // Print values
  printf("%d %c %s", s1.myNum, s1.myLetter, s1.myString);

  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a structure variable and assign values to it

content.text: Note: The order of the inserted values must match the order of the variable types declared in the structure (13 for int, 'B' for char, etc).
content.html: Note: The order of the inserted values must match the order of the variable types declared in the structure (13 for int, 'B' for char, etc).

content.text: Copy Structures
You can also assign one structure to another.
content.html: You can also assign one structure to another.

content.text: In the following example, the values of s1 are copied to s2:
content.html: In the following example, the values of s1 are copied to s2:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
struct myStructure s1 = {13, 'B', "Some text"};struct myStructure s2;
    s2 = s1;

content.code:
struct myStructure s1 = {13, 'B', "Some text"};struct myStructure s2;
s2 = s1;

syntax_highlighting.text:
struct myStructure s1 = {13, 'B', "Some text"};struct myStructure s2;
 s2 = s1;

content.code_html:
struct myStructure s1 = {13, 'B', "Some text"};
struct myStructure s2;

s2 = s1;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
struct myStructure s1 = {13, 'B', "Some text"};struct myStructure s2;
    s2 = s1;

content.text: Modify Values
If you want to change/modify a value, you can use the dot syntax ( . ).
content.html: If you want to change/modify a value, you can use the dot syntax (.).

content.text: And to modify a string value, the strcpy() function is useful again:
content.html: And to modify a string value, the strcpy() function is useful again:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a structure variable and assign values to it

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a structure variable and assign values to it

content.code_html:
struct myStructure {
  int myNum;
  char myLetter;
  char myString[30];
};

int main() {
  // Create a structure variable and assign values to it
  struct myStructure s1 = {13, 'B', "Some text"};

  // Modify values
  s1.myNum = 30;
  s1.myLetter = 'C';
  strcpy(s1.myString, "Something else");

  // Print values
  printf("%d %c %s", s1.myNum, s1.myLetter, s1.myString);

  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a structure variable and assign values to it

content.text: Modifying values are especially useful when you copy structure values:
content.html: Modifying values are especially useful when you copy structure values:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create a structure variable and assign values to itstruct 
    myStructure s1 = {13, 'B', "Some text"};// Create another structure 
    variablestruct myStructure s2;// Copy s1 values to s2s2 = 
    s1;// Change s2 valuess2.myNum = 30;s2.myLetter = 'C';strcpy(s2.myString, 
    "Something else");// Print valuesprintf("%d %c 
    %s\n", s1.myNum, s1.myLetter, s1.myString);printf("%d %c 
    %s\n", s2.myNum, s2.myLetter, s2.myString);
// Create a structure variable and assign values to it

content.code:
// Create a structure variable and assign values to itstruct
myStructure s1 = {13, 'B', "Some text"};// Create another structure
variablestruct myStructure s2;// Copy s1 values to s2s2 =
s1;// Change s2 valuess2.myNum = 30;s2.myLetter = 'C';strcpy(s2.myString,
"Something else");// Print valuesprintf("%d %c
%s\n", s1.myNum, s1.myLetter, s1.myString);printf("%d %c
%s\n", s2.myNum, s2.myLetter, s2.myString);

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create a structure variable and assign values to itstruct 
    myStructure s1 = {13, 'B', "Some text"};// Create another structure 
    variablestruct myStructure s2;// Copy s1 values to s2s2 = 
    s1;// Change s2 valuess2.myNum = 30;s2.myLetter = 'C';strcpy(s2.myString, 
 "Something else");// Print valuesprintf("%d %c 
    %s\n", s1.myNum, s1.myLetter, s1.myString);printf("%d %c 
    %s\n", s2.myNum, s2.myLetter, s2.myString);
// Create a structure variable and assign values to it

content.code_html:
// Create a structure variable and assign values to it
struct myStructure s1 = {13, 'B', "Some text"};

// Create another structure variable
struct myStructure s2;

// Copy s1 values to s2
s2 = s1;

// Change s2 values
s2.myNum = 30;
s2.myLetter = 'C';
strcpy(s2.myString, "Something else");

// Print values
printf("%d %c %s\n", s1.myNum, s1.myLetter, s1.myString);
printf("%d %c %s\n", s2.myNum, s2.myLetter, s2.myString);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:

    myStructure s1 = {13, 'B', "Some text"};// Create another structure 
    variablestruct myStructure s2;// Copy s1 values to s2s2 = 
    s1;// Change s2 valuess2.myNum = 30;s2.myLetter = 'C';strcpy(s2.myString, 
    "Something else");// Print valuesprintf("%d %c 
    %s\n", s1.myNum, s1.myLetter, s1.myString);printf("%d %c 
    %s\n", s2.myNum, s2.myLetter, s2.myString);
// Create a structure variable and assign values to it

content.text: Ok, so, how are structures useful?

Imagine you have to write a program to store different information about Cars, such as brand, model, and year. What's great about structures is that you can create a single "Car template" and use it for every cars you make. See below for a real life example.
content.html: Imagine you have to write a program to store different information about Cars, such as brand, model, and year. What's great about structures is that you can create a single "Car template" and use it for every cars you make. See below for a real life example.

content.text: Real-Life Example
Use a structure to store different information about Cars:
content.html: Use a structure to store different information about Cars:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
struct Car {  char brand[50];  char model[50];  int 
  year;};int main() {  struct Car car1 = {"BMW", "X5", 
  1999};  struct Car car2 = {"Ford", "Mustang", 1969};  struct 
  Car car3 = {"Toyota", "Corolla", 2011};  printf("%s %s %d\n", 
  car1.brand, car1.model, car1.year);  printf("%s %s %d\n", car2.brand, 
  car2.model, car2.year);  printf("%s %s %d\n", car3.brand, car3.model, 
  car3.year);  return 0;}

content.code:
struct Car {  char brand[50];  char model[50];  int
year;};int main() {  struct Car car1 = {"BMW", "X5",
1999};  struct Car car2 = {"Ford", "Mustang", 1969};  struct
Car car3 = {"Toyota", "Corolla", 2011};  printf("%s %s %d\n",
car1.brand, car1.model, car1.year);  printf("%s %s %d\n", car2.brand,
car2.model, car2.year);  printf("%s %s %d\n", car3.brand, car3.model,
car3.year);  return 0;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
struct Car {  char brand[50];  char model[50];  int 
  year;};int main() {  struct Car car1 = {"BMW", "X5", 
 1999};  struct Car car2 = {"Ford", "Mustang", 1969};  struct 
  Car car3 = {"Toyota", "Corolla", 2011};  printf("%s %s %d\n", 
  car1.brand, car1.model, car1.year);  printf("%s %s %d\n", car2.brand, 
  car2.model, car2.year);  printf("%s %s %d\n", car3.brand, car3.model, 
  car3.year);  return 0;}

content.code_html:
struct Car {
  char brand[50];
  char model[50];
  int year;
};

int main() {
  struct Car car1 = {"BMW", "X5", 1999};
  struct Car car2 = {"Ford", "Mustang", 1969};
  struct Car car3 = {"Toyota", "Corolla", 2011};

  printf("%s %s %d\n", car1.brand, car1.model, car1.year);
  printf("%s %s %d\n", car2.brand, car2.model, car2.year);
  printf("%s %s %d\n", car3.brand, car3.model, car3.year);

  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
struct Car {  char brand[50];  char model[50];  int 
  year;};int main() {  struct Car car1 = {"BMW", "X5", 
  1999};  struct Car car2 = {"Ford", "Mustang", 1969};  struct 
  Car car3 = {"Toyota", "Corolla", 2011};  printf("%s %s %d\n", 
  car1.brand, car1.model, car1.year);  printf("%s %s %d\n", car2.brand, 
  car2.model, car2.year);  printf("%s %s %d\n", car3.brand, car3.model, 
  car3.year);  return 0;}
